channel.title: Comments on: Lost Boys
channel.description: Scattered pages from an apocryphal diary

item.title: By: Drey
item.dc:creator: Drey
item.description:
I loved that about Braid and Limbo. Sometimes I thought I had encountered a glitch in the game. The puzzle seemed so impossible. It was very rewarding to figure it out.
Mass Effect 2 had an emotional impact on me after the big final mission. I kept playing the game and whenever I had to select a party and I saw those empty slots where teammates used to be, I'd mourn them and wonder if I could have saved them.
I haven't played Rameses or Kaged, but I will look them up and download them to my iPad.

item.title: By: Jeff
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
I actually just finished Limbo a few minutes ago. I played Braid several months ago. I refrained from reading your review on Bastion since I haven't played it yet.
What struck me most about these games was how I was able to overcome the seemingly impossible tasks set before me. I remember thinking "I'll never figure this out" but then, soon enough, I'd figure it out.
Maybe this is uncool to say, but the Mass Effect games really packed an emotional punch for me. For three days after I finished the first one (and again after the finishing the second one) I really couldn't do anything else but think about what happened.
Have you delved much into the indie text adventure (or "interactive fiction") scene? There's some really experimental, cool, and powerful stuff out there. I'd recommend checking out "Rameses: A Tale of Heroes" by Stephen Bond and "Kaged" by Ian Finley. I played through both of those years ago, and they still resonate with me.
